awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Controls on along-strike variations in locked and creeping megathrust behavior at the Hikuran convergent margin
awd_abstract_narration:
Collaborative Research: Controls on along-strike variations in locked and creeping megathrust behavior at the Hikurangi convergent margin

The physical processes dictating the spectrum of fault slip modes (spanning destructive earthquakes to slow slip events and aseismic creep) and the links between these behaviors and long-term morphotectonic evolution of subduction systems are not understood. There is a fundamental need to address this important problem with an integrated, system-level approach combining geodynamical modeling with high-quality geophysical and geological constraints on subduction margin characteristics.

This project will conduct an interdisciplinary, multinational collaborative program involving the USA, New Zealand, Japan and the UK to evaluate system-level controls on processes that govern both slip behavior and long-term deformation at subduction zones. The focus is on the Hikurangi margin in New Zealand, where GPS data show a transition in slip behavior from predominantly stick-slip in the south to aseismic creep in the northern North Island, and where a wide range of subduction-related processes and characteristics vary along-strike. The aim is to rigorously investigate the feedbacks between plate interface slip behavior, solid and fluid mass fluxes, and manifestations of plate boundary mechanics in the long-term geological record that likely reflect common driving processes linking forearc uplift, sediment transfer and underplating, plate boundary strength, and seismogenesis. The Principal Investigators will address this important problem through an integrated approach combining large-scale seismic imaging, paleoseismology, and geomorphology, focused through the lens of state-of-the-art numerical modelling.

por.por_cntn:
Many of the world's most populated centers are located near plate boundaries where earthquakes and tsunamis pose significant risk. Lessons learned in the wake of recent earthquakes in Sumatra and Japan provide valuable insight into the intensity of events that can be expected in the future. Over the last few decades, the use of GPS instrumentation coupled with increasingly sophisticated modeling has shed light on the mechanisms that generate earthquakes and tsunamis. However, because instrumental data are short-term (decades to centuries) and span only fractions of a full earthquake cycle, many aspects of plate boundary processes, particularly the frequency at which earthquakes and tsunamis occur, remain unclear.  A robust understanding of the seismic risk along the Hikurangi coastline of New Zealand is of particular importance given the complicated tectonics of the area and the lack of longterm geologic reconstructions of earthquakes and tsunamis.

 

The field team, consisting of members from the United States, Canada, and New Zealand, completed multiple field expeditions to the Hikurangi coast of New Zealand's north island.  More than ten locations along the Hawke's Bay and Wairarapa coasts were explored for earthquake and tsunami evidence, with over 40 sediment cores and 100 surface samples collected.  A major focus area of the project was Hawke's Bay, where an earthquake in 1931 caused 1.0 - 1.5 m of uplift at Ahuriri Lagoon, resulting in sustained subaerial exposure of the lagoon sediment.  Three anomalous sandy deposits underlying the uplifted 1931 surface were investigated to better understand the earthquake and tsunami history for the region.  An innovative suite of stratigraphic, grain size, microfossil, and shell taphonomic analyses point to a tsunami origin for the anomalous sandy deposits.  Radiocarbon dating on 22 articulated bivalves from the collected cores indicates that these tsunami events occurred within the last 980 years, which suggests a tsunami recurrence interval of ~300 years. Previous estimates of subduction earthquake recurrence intervals are on the order of ~1,000 - 1,400 years, which is much longer than our estimated tsunami recurrence interval.  Ongoing research targeting coseismic subsidence coincident with the inferred tsunami deposits will elucidate the origin of the tsunami events (i.e., megathrust along the Hikurangi Margin or upper plate faulting) and better constrain the recurrence interval. An improved understanding of source and timing of earthquakes and tsunamis has major implications for coastal communities of Hawke's Bay because tsunami hazards may be more frequent than previously estimated.

 

The outreach strategy developed as part of this study involved the participation of undergraduate and graduate students, government scientists, professors, media representatives, and Maori community leaders. The diverse activities to increase public awareness and education about earthquake hazards and paleoseismology included: (1) An educational video called "Tsunami Hunters or Scientists" was co-developed by the field team and the New Zealand-based East Coast Lab, a public outreach organization that focuses on educating citizens about earthquake hazards; (2) Two news outlets in New Zealand (Wairoa Star and Gisborne Herald) reported on our team’s field activities and emerging results; (3) Concepts and results gained from this research were integrated into undergraduate and graduate courses at University of Southern Mississippi and Simon Fraser University.  Cores collected from Hawke's Bay formed the basis of two undergraduate theses and were used in laboratory exercises in several undergraduate courses; and (4) Findings from this study were disseminated via a "Pint of Science" public lecture and a Curiosity Collider documentary called "Ground Swell" that was featured in "Her Story: Canadian Women Scientists".  The documentary short film is rooted in tsunami science but has a major focus on the importance of female mentorship in STEM subjects.
